head.title: A Crowded Collection Finds New Space

identified-content.org: Museum of the City of New York
identified-content.classifier: Top/Classifieds/Job Market/Job Categories/Technology, Telecommunications and Internet

hedline.hl1: A Crowded Collection Finds New Space

abstract.p: Museum of City of New York's new Web site described; photos (New York Online column) (M)

block.p: The Museum of the City of New York is taking advantage of free real estate in cyberspace.

Established in 1923 to preserve the city's artifacts, the museum was originally housed at Gracie Mansion, but moved five years later to a larger building at Fifth Avenue and 103rd Street. Since then, the museum has acquired more than 1.5 million objects, placing enormous pressure on its exhibition space.
The Museum of the City of New York is taking advantage of free real estate in cyberspace.

Established in 1923 to preserve the city's artifacts, the museum was originally housed at Gracie Mansion, but moved five years later to a larger building at Fifth Avenue and 103rd Street. Since then, the museum has acquired more than 1.5 million objects, placing enormous pressure on its exhibition space.

''The Web gives us a whole new outlet,'' said Peter Simmons, the museum's chief information officer. ''We get about 100 exhibition proposals from our staff each year, and maybe a dozen move forward. Many have merit, but we don't have the space or resources.''

The site appeared in late summer, replacing an earlier version that ''was literally a brochure,'' Mr. Simmons said. It currently has 13 virtual exhibitions. Some were adapted from shows at the museum, but most could not be physically mounted for one reason or another.
''The 18th-century shoes of New York are too fragile,'' Mr. Simmons said, referring to an online exhibition. ''For conservation reasons, it would have been impossible to display them.''
Other shows, like a collection of paper fans, were initially considered too esoteric. But its online popularity may lead the museum to install an actual show.

WHAT YOU SEE -- From the home page, click on ''Features'' to visit the online galleries. Highlights include ''Painting the Town,'' a catalog of cityscape portraits from 1800 to the present; ''New York Before the War,'' a retrospective of photographs commissioned by the Works Progress Administration; and ''New York in Love,'' an assortment of valentines exchanged between long-lost lovers. Other sections offer information about the museum's full archives, coming events and research help.

LINKS -- To a vast collection of historical resources on the Web, including the Gotham Center at the City University of New York; the Forgotten City, ''the infrastructure of a lost metropolis,'' with images of buildings that no longer exist; and the 1964 World's Fair in Queens. There are also links to the NYC Historical Collections, a compendium of 45 historical societies from the Staten Island Historical Society to the Statute of Liberty National Monument.
WHAT YOU GET -- Exhibitions from the Museum of the City of New York created for the Web.
